repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Participatory Management of
            Protected Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Participatory Management
            of Protected Areas Project for Peru were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            low or negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: innovations should be piloted in more than
            one area. Although this adds a layer of complexity, it will
            test the innovation in a variety of circumstances.
            Attempting to fine-tune the criteria and select a pilot that
            appears to have the best conditions risks failure of the
            test, as unforeseen circumstances may arise that cannot be
            resolved. The importance of communications in establishing
            the transparency and trust needed for effective
            participation of a range of diverse stakeholders has already
            been mentioned. Communications must be tailored to address
            local interests and concerns. A communications strategy
            should be conceived of broadly, going beyond dissemination
            of information to promoting forums, processes, mechanisms,
            and instruments for inclusion. The willingness of local
            populations and communities to become involved in
            conservation tasks is enormous. Participatory management
            will progress and succeed to the extent that there is shared
            information and analysis and the parties perceive the
            distribution of costs and benefits as equitable. Economic
            interests may be more powerful than environmental awareness
            as a motivation for participation. Thus environmental
            awareness raising programs will not be enough to achieve
            effective participation. A long-term results-oriented
            management approach, such as the Administration Contract
            instrument, may more effectively promote efficiency than the
            more traditional project-specific implementation contract.
            The requirement for the contractor to make a financial
            commitment also promotes efficiency. It is important,
            however, to allow the financial commitment to be fulfilled
            progressively in order not to discriminate against smaller
            partners that may have less short-term financial capacity.
            It should not be assumed that the Borrower agencies that
            participated in project preparation and are to be involved
            in its implementation will have a clear, much less common,
            view of the objectives, strategy, and activities of the
            project, particularly as the preparation phase may be
            lengthy and there may be rotation of key staff during it.
            Project launch to promote a common understanding and buy-in
            is, therefore, critical.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Participatory Management of
            Protected Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Participatory Management of
            Protected Areas Project for Peru's development
            objectives are: i) insure biodiversity conservation by
            increasing the involvement of civil society institutions and
            the private sector in planning and sustainable management of
            at least five protected areas (PA) of the Peruvian System of
            Natural Protected Areas (SINANPE), and one PA to be created
            during project implementation; and ii) obtain sustainability
            for the financing of recurrent cost in SINANPE. The project
            will build upon the experience gained during the first GEF
            Grant to PROFONANPE, supporting the Trus Fund's
            establishment and development of its capacity to attract
            financial resources for conservation. The project has three
            major components: 1) participatory protected area management
            by involving civil society, private sector and local
            community organizations in the decision making process and
            management of the PAs; 2) institutional development to
            consolidate PA management through the strengthening of
            INRENA, PROFONANPE, PAMCs, civil society organizations and
            private sector to manage the PAs collaboratively; 3) PA
            financing, administration, monitoring and evaluation, and
            information dissemination in order to increase the
            PROFONANPE endowment fund, design and implement a SINANPE
            financing strategy.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Participatory Management of
            Protected Areas Project : social assessment and strategy

abstracts.cdata!:
This social assessment of the
            Participatory Management and Protected Areas (PAs) Project
            for Peru discusses potentially adverse social impacts
            identified through the social assessment and public
            consultation process during preparation. First, certain
            zoning categories defined in the Management Plans may result
            in limiting or eliminating public access to relevant areas
            (strict conservation areas). Second, five of the six
            protected areas are populated by ethnic or indigenous
            groups, most of which live in extreme poverty and depend on
            subsistence agriculture and natural resources exploitation.
            Demographic growth and consumption patterns have combined
            and increased pressure on PA lands and natural resources.
            Land tenure disputes exist in three of the five areas and
            will not be resolved by this project. The project promoted
            private involvement in PA management through concessions,
            which has been perceived by some communities as adversely
            affecting their welfare. Lastly there is a risk that the
            privatization approach may further complicate the
            relationship existing between the National Institute for
            Natural Resources (INRENA) and the communities and result in
            impeding PA management. To address these issues, the
            project's social strategy calls for adopting a Process
            Framework and an Indigenous Peoples Development Framework,
            and promoting public participation in project-supported PAs.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Participatory Management of
            Protected Areas Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment identifies
            likely adverse environmental impacts connected with the
            Participatory Management of Protected Areas Project in six
            categories:: (i) load capacity; (ii) visual impact; (iii)
            natural environment deterioration; (iv) solid and liquid
            waste; (v) fire and emissions; and (vi) hosts and visitors
            security. Some of those impacts are discussed in this
            summary: Camping sites will be located strategically to
            avoid harming vegetation, forest animals and
            plants-especially endangered species-and water and soil.
            Adhering to camping ethics will be reinforced with visitors.
            Drainage systems will be built to protect the infrastructure
            of protected areas from flooding. Visitors will be educated
            on the prohibition of collecting plants and animals, proper
            waste disposal, restricted access areas, and regulations for
            using footpaths, etc. Solar, wind or water will be used as
            energy sources. Latrines and other installations will
            collect and store liquid and solid waste. Fire emergency
            plans will be issued. Existing infrastructure will be
            adapted to blend in visually with its surroundings or
            replaced and cables will be buried. Electric generators will
            be operated within closed structures to prevent spills and
            reduce noise. Road repair will be done with light equipment
            to avoid damage to vegetation and to soil. Where roads would
            possibly interfere with forest animals, adequate signage
            will be posted. The number of vehicles will be limited in
            sensitive environs.
